Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Scent-mediated diversification of flowers and moths across western North America
Award.AbstractNarration:
Relationships among flowering plants and insects represent one of the great engines of terrestrial diversity. Plant scents are important drivers of these relationships (herbivory, plant defense, pollination), but remain poorly integrated into our understanding of floral evolution and pollination ecology. This study examines the role of floral scent in the diversification of the western North American evening primroses (Onagraceae) and their pollinators (hawkmoths, bees) and floral and seed predators (Mompha moths). Hypotheses that integrate across the genetic, phylogenetic, and functional dimensions of biodiversity are developed from the Geographic Mosaic Theory of Coevolution, which posits that variation in plant-animal interactions across the distribution of a species creates shifting evolutionary trajectories that drive local diversification. The research examines functional trait variation and selective forces in the field and experimental arrays, the genetic basis of the variation from the population to phylogenetic level using comparative genomics, and patterns of phylogenetic diversity in Onagraceae and Mompha. Mompha is a poorly understood genus that is the only known lepidopteran group to specialize on Onagraceae.

Few studies have tested the full spectrum of plant fitness outcomes when volatiles attract both mutualists and enemies, and no current studies have investigated scent-driven, geographic diversification in groups of interacting organisms. The hidden diversity of floral and seed predators and their potential as selective agents constitutes a considerable gap in pollinator-centric understanding of floral evolution. The integration of chemical ecology and comparative genomics provides a first attempt to explore the impact of past selective pressures on current patterns of diversity in non-model organisms. Additionally, the investigators will engage over 200 students (high school - graduate school, interns, and postdocs) in field work, experiments, and genomics/informatics activities. Private and public land owners and volunteers will participate in and/or be informed of conservation-focused components of this study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although floral scent is considered fanciful by non-scientists and trivial by pollination biologists, recent studies have revealed that floral volatile compounds play important roles in pollinator attraction and learning, from generalized (honey bees, bumblebees) pollinators servicing crop plants to specialized (orchid bees, bats) pollinators sustaining biological diversity. Our study focused on a rare evening primrose plant, Oenothera harringtonii, endemic to the shortgrass prairies of south-central Colorado, USA. We studied all known populations of this plant between Colorado Springs and Trinidad and discovered striking geographic variation in floral scent: populations northwest of Walsenburg CO smelled strongly of linalool, a common floral fragrance found in bergamot oil, whereas populations to the southeast lacked this compound. Because floral volatiles facilitate communication between plants and pollinators, we likened this geographic variation to a regional dialect in floral chemistry.

We tested and falsified alternative hypotheses that might explain this geographic pattern, including the potential for different local pollinators or herbivores, inbreeding effects (genetic drift) due to local isolation and differences in soil quality or micronutrients. Our ecological, genetic and soil chemical data allow us to reject each of these hypotheses, as the plants are amply pollinated by hawkmoths across their range, show no local genetic race formation and are limited to the same kind of silty soil across the Arkansas River drainage. Instead, we found that a small, non-pollinating moth, Mompha definitella, attacks Oenothera plants more frequently when flowers smell of linalool and destroys more seeds when plants are small, with fewer flowers. When this study was extended to many species of Oenothera across southwestern USA, a similar pattern was found, such that species associated with Mompha moths were more likely to have variation in floral scent, but not floral morphology.

Intellectual Merit: Biologists tend to "silo" the studies of herbivory (plant defense against animals that eat them) and pollination, but our study underscores the importance of considering how natural enemies impact reproductive ecology. Because evening primroses are amply pollinated by hawkmoths, additional pollinator attraction has minimal effects on seed production, whereas the effects of eavesdropping on pollinator attractant odors by seed predators such as Mompha moths can be devastating. Such examples are known from agricultural plants (e.g. weevils on strawberry flowers), but our study suggests that floral scent, color and other traits may be shaped as strongly by enemies as they are by pollinators. Our study is nearly unique in its combination of population genetics, chemical ecology, insect behavior, structural equation (statistical) modeling and manipulative field ecological experiments across a geographic scale. It is among the first to re-focus comparative studies of floral scent from the level of species to the level of population, where most genetic and evolutionary change occurs.

Broader Impacts: Our study connects the dots between isolated "special cases" of squash pollination and wild parsnip, introduced to North America from Europe, to illustrate the importance of natural enemies to the pollination success of wild plants and domesticated crops. We analyzed an unprecedented number of floral scent samples from across the American southwest using unbiased chemical analytical and statistical methods, which should be broadly applicable to others working in agriculture and conservation. Our combined field and lab approaches were used to train several students and visiting scientists at Cornell, drew unexpected connections between organic chemistry and pollination biology, and supported outreach activities at Cornell's Entomology Department's "Insectapalooza" events each fall, which attract an average of 3000 visitors from NY state's southern tier to learn about pollination services, pest control and biological diversity in a heavily agricultural region.
